Hijas de Demi Moore hablan del alcoholismo de su madre: “Era como si viniera un monstruo”
Hijas de Demi Moore hablaron del alcoholismo de su madre. Mira todo lo que dijeron.
04 Nov 2019, 16:00 by Ana Morocho
Tallullah Willis, hija de Demi Moore, recordó en una entrevista las duras recaídas que tuvo su madre cuando era adicta. Junto a sus hermanas Scott y Rumer, la joven señaló que estos terribles momentos aún los tiene en su mente.



La actriz publicó recientemente sus memorias, donde cuenta terribles pasajes de su vida y su adicción, en las cuales las más afectadas fueron sus tres hijas, productos del matrimonio que tuvo con Bruce Willis.
Después que saliera a la venta el libro de Demi Moore (llamado Inside Out); Rumer, de 31 años, Scout, de 28, y Tallulah, de 25, se reunieron con su madre en el programa Red Table Talk, y hablaron de esta etapa tan tormentosa de la actriz, su alcoholismo.



"Era como si el sol se ocultara, como si llegara un monstruo", señaló Tallullah, una de las hijas de Demi Moore.
"Recuerdo cómo la ansiedad recorría todo mi cuerpo cuando me daba cuenta de que sus ojos estaban un poco más cerrados, o por la manera en la que hablaba. O porque era más cariñosa conmigo si no estaba sobria", acotó.
"Era terrorífico", acotó Rumer, su hermana mayor. "Era muy extraño, y había momentos en los que sentía mucha irritación", detalló Tallullah.



"Me acuerdo de estar muy enfadada y de tratarla como si fuera una niña, hablarle como si fuera una niña. No era la madre con la que habíamos crecido", acotó sobre la artista de 56 años.
Cabe indicar que fuentes cercanas a la familia Willis-Moore, indicaron a la revista People que durante su periodo de alcoholismo, la actriz "estaba sufriendo muchísimo mentalmente y no se cuidaba. No mantenía una buena relación con sus hijas y su vida era un caos".



"Demi se siente mal por los años en los que no estuvo sana y ahora está intentando arreglarlo. Sus hijas son fantásticas. Demi está implicada en su día a día y ellas le dan todo su apoyo. Les encanta que haya escrito unas memorias", dijeron.

Demi Moore's daughters talk about her mother's alcoholism: "It was as if a monster was coming"
Demi Moore's daughters talked about her mother's alcoholism. Look at everything they said.
04 Nov 2019, 16:00 by Ana Morocho
Tallullah Willis, daughter of Demi Moore, recalled in an interview the severe relapses her mother had when she was addicted. Together with her sisters Scott and Rumer, the young woman said that these terrible moments still have them in her mind.



The actress recently published her memoirs, where she tells terrible passages of her life and her addiction, in which the most affected were her three daughters, products of the marriage she had with Bruce Willis.
After Demi Moore's book (called Inside Out) went on sale; Rumer, 31, Scout, 28, and Tallulah, 25, met with his mother on the Red Table Talk program, and talked about this stormy stage of the actress, her alcoholism.



"It was as if the sun was setting, as if a monster were coming," said Tallullah, one of Demi Moore's daughters.
"I remember how anxiety ran through my whole body when I realized that his eyes were a little more closed, or because of the way he spoke. Or because he was more affectionate to me if I wasn't sober," he said.
"It was terrifying," said Rumer, his older sister. "It was very strange, and there were times when I was very irritated," Tallullah said.



"I remember being very angry and treating her like she was a girl, talking to her like she was a girl. She wasn't the mother we had grown up with," he said of the 56-year-old artist.
It should be noted that sources close to the Willis-Moore family told People magazine that during her period of alcoholism, the actress "was suffering very much mentally and did not take care of herself. She did not maintain a good relationship with her daughters and her life was chaos ".



"Demi feels bad for the years in which she was not healthy and is now trying to fix it. Her daughters are fantastic. Demi is involved in her day-to-day life and they give her full support. They love that she wrote some memoirs," they said
